1. A 38-year-old male presents with a 2-year history of gradual onset resting tremor predominantly affecting his right hand, accompanied by stiffness and slowness of movement. He reports difficulty initiating movements and occasional micrographia, which has impacted his work as a graphic designer. There is a family history of Parkinson's disease diagnosed in a paternal uncle in his 40s. On examination, he exhibits cogwheel rigidity and mild bradykinesia on the right side, with diminished arm swing during gait. He denies significant cognitive changes but feels increasingly fatigued and anxious. Brain MRI is unremarkable, and DaTscan shows reduced dopamine transporter uptake in the left striatum. Genetic testing reveals a pathogenic mutation consistent with early-onset Parkinson’s disease type 20. He has started low-dose levodopa with improvement in motor symptoms but complains of mild nausea as a side effect.
